issue.title: Bug: invalid pointer while importing an animated FBX model

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Global flag to mark a deviation from expected behaviour

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
While importing the free "Black Dragon with Idle Animation" model (in its original FBX v7.4 format from Sketchfab), Assimp prints "free(): invalid pointer" to  `stderr` and aborts.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Register a (free) account at the Sketchfab.com website and log in.
2. Browse to https://sketchfab.com/3d-models/black-dragon-with-idle-animation-fb0053a2e59b43868e934c239bf4eb36#download
3. Click on the blue "Download" button to the right of "fbx Original format".
4. Unzip the downloaded file.
5. Load the FBX file using `aiImportFile(filename, aiProcess_Triangulate)`

**Expected behavior**
`aiImportFile()` should return a valid and complete data structure.

**Screenshots**
With verbose logging enabled, the following messages are printed to the console:
```console
Info,  T0: Load Models/Issue/source/ef2da8ba53194e35a4be77969cff3949.fbx.fbx
Debug, T0: Assimp 5.2.0 amd64 gcc shared singlethreadedsingle : 
Info,  T0: Found a matching importer for this file format: Autodesk FBX Importer.
Info,  T0: Import root directory is 'Models/Issue/source/'
Debug, T0: Reading FBX file
Debug, T0: Tokenizing binary FBX file
Debug, T0: FBX version: 7400
Debug, T0: Parsing FBX tokens
Debug, T0: Creating FBX Document
Debug, T0: FBX Version: 7400
Warn,  T0: FBX-DOM (TOK_KEY, offset 0x28c0c7) encountered duplicate object id, ignoring first occurrence
free(): invalid pointer
```

**Platform**
 - OS: Mint Linux
 - Browser: Firefox
 - Version: LWJGL v3.3.3, which was built from Assimp commit 59b12344 (13 September 2023)

**Additional context**
The test data are licensed Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial. I'm unsure whether it's appropriate to upload here. If it is, let me know, and I'll do so.

comment.body:
> Next I'd like to build a DEBUG version of the `assimp` binary, so I can analyze the resulting coredump. How would I do that?

The standard CMake way: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/variable/CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE.html

comment.body:
At Git hash 0c4d5909 the command `bin/assimp info issue5289.fbx` completes normally.
At Git hash 18b6cffe the command `bin/assimp info issue5289.fbx` dumps core.
Therefore, the regression was introduced into the "master" branch on 16 May 2023, by pull request #5096 .

Next I'd like to build a DEBUG version of the `assimp` binary. How would I do that?

comment.body:
You should set it from command line
```
cmake -DASSIMP_BUILD_ASSIMP_TOOLS=On
```
because having local changes interferes with bisect.

Also you should not be building directly in source directory. Create a separate `build` directory under it and run from there
```
cmake -DASSIMP_BUILD_ASSIMP_TOOLS=On ..
```
If you did it successfully there should be an `assimp` binary under directory `bin`.

comment.body:
Progress at my end...
1. edited "MakeLists.txt" to build supplementary tools:
```diff
--- a/CMakeLists.txt
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ OPTION( ASSIMP_NO_EXPORT
 )
 OPTION( ASSIMP_BUILD_ASSIMP_TOOLS
   "If the supplementary tools for Assimp are built in addition to the library."
-  OFF
+  ON
 )
 OPTION ( ASSIMP_BUILD_SAMPLES
   "If the official samples are built as well (needs Glut)."
```

2. `cmake CmakeLists.txt`
3. `cmake --build . -j 4`

So far, so good. Now where do I find the `assimp` tool binary? (I expect to find it in the `bin` directory, but it's not there.)

issue.title: unit tests using "non-public" classes

labels.name: Techdebt
labels.description: Technical dept which needs to get solved.

issue.body:
for the Debian package, i try to strip down the symbols exported by `libassimp` to a bare minimum.
the reasoning is:
- avoid nameclashes (admittedly rather unlikely)
- avoid namespace pollution in general
- prevent consumers of `libassimp` to accidentally use a symbol that is not part of the stable API

the stable API is defined as what goes into the public headers.

for this, I use a [version-script](https://salsa.debian.org/debian/assimp/-/blob/master/debian/libassimp.ver) which is passed via `-DCMAKE_SHARED_LINKER_FLAGS="-Wl,--version-script=libassimp.ver"`

this works nicely for stripping down the library.

**however** stripping down the exported symbols also completely and utterly breaks the unit-tests, which heavily rely on being able to use symbols that are not available in public headers.

E.g. the `utScenePreprocessor` uses the `Assimp::ScenePreprocessor` class: https://github.com/assimp/assimp/blob/1169d3bc8cdd3a8c1abfce90491c57e0186ed4cc/test/unit/utScenePreprocessor.cpp#L85

Obviously, using internal classes in the test-suite allows for very specific tests that are not too complicated to write.
Which is a good thing (as it allows for more testing).

So I'm in a bit of a dilemma: either strip down the symbols, xor have unit-tests.

would it be reasonable to ask for a class of unit-tests that only use the public API and still test a significant portion of the code?

comment.body:
i also got feedback from the Debian folks how they handle this

> maybe build two versions of the library - the clean one for installation, and the extras-included one for the unit tests?

and 

> what I did in RE2 was have the tests link twice. Dynamically for the public ABI, statically for private symbols. It's eww, but it's worked well and upstream adopted the patch years ago

and 
> fwiw, that's what I do in `notmuch` as well
> at least the unit tests using private API are marked there, and could be disabled separately

pull_request.title: use size in order to be compatible with float and double
pull_request.body: This fixes a compilation error of the lib when `ASSIMP_DOUBLE_PRECISION` is set to `ON`

issue.title: unit tests using "non-public" classes

labels.name: Techdebt
labels.description: Technical dept which needs to get solved.

issue.body:
for the Debian package, i try to strip down the symbols exported by `libassimp` to a bare minimum.
the reasoning is:
- avoid nameclashes (admittedly rather unlikely)
- avoid namespace pollution in general
- prevent consumers of `libassimp` to accidentally use a symbol that is not part of the stable API

the stable API is defined as what goes into the public headers.

for this, I use a [version-script](https://salsa.debian.org/debian/assimp/-/blob/master/debian/libassimp.ver) which is passed via `-DCMAKE_SHARED_LINKER_FLAGS="-Wl,--version-script=libassimp.ver"`

this works nicely for stripping down the library.

**however** stripping down the exported symbols also completely and utterly breaks the unit-tests, which heavily rely on being able to use symbols that are not available in public headers.

E.g. the `utScenePreprocessor` uses the `Assimp::ScenePreprocessor` class: https://github.com/assimp/assimp/blob/1169d3bc8cdd3a8c1abfce90491c57e0186ed4cc/test/unit/utScenePreprocessor.cpp#L85

Obviously, using internal classes in the test-suite allows for very specific tests that are not too complicated to write.
Which is a good thing (as it allows for more testing).

So I'm in a bit of a dilemma: either strip down the symbols, xor have unit-tests.

would it be reasonable to ask for a class of unit-tests that only use the public API and still test a significant portion of the code?

comment.body:
i guess the best way would be to strip down the symbols only during deployment of the libassimp library (after the unit-tests are run).

Unfortunately, I have no idea how to do that...
